Controllable synthesis of honeycomb-structured ZnO nanomaterials for photocatalytic degradation of methylene blue

Article history: Received 20 May 2019 Received in revised form 1 June 2019 Accepted 7 June 2019 Available online 7 June 2019
Keywords: Nanocrystalline materials Semiconductors ZnO Photocatalytic Honeycomb-structured
a b s t r a c t
Nano-carbon spheres with a controllable particle size were prepared by a hydrothermal method, and ZnO nanomaterials with three-dimensional honeycomb structures were successfully fabricated by a liquid-phase coating method using the carbon spheres as the template. The structural and morphological characterizations show that the honeycomb size and pore structure of the honeycomb-structured ZnO nanomaterials can be achieved by adjusting the hydrothermal temperature for preparing carbon spheres and the molar ratio of carbon sphere to zinc acetate. The synthesized ZnO samples exhibit high specific surface area and more surface-active sites. The degradation rate of methylene blue by the honeycombstructured ZnO nanomaterials with a honeycomb size of 80 nm and a pore wall thickness of 10 nm reaches 95% within 90 min, which exhibits an enhancement of 108% compared with that observed for conventional micron-sized ZnO. It reveals that the structure of honeycomb-like ZnO nanomaterials can be fabricated controllably, further enhancing their surface adsorption capacity and photocatalytic reactivity.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nano-sized ZnO exhibits high specific surface area and high surface activity, which can be widely used as gas-sensitive materials and catalysts, and the material plays a key role in gas monitoring and environmental control [1–3]. However, the high energy of the nanoparticle surface typically leads to aggregation, thereby decreasing the specific surface area as well as the active sites. To solve this issue, the most suitable approaches involve the increase of surface-reaction-active sites by the loading of noble metals [4] and specializing surface morphology (such as linear [5] and filmlike [6]). Recently, honeycomb-like ZnO nanostructures have been successfully synthesized by some methods [7,8]. These structures exhibit high specific surface area, and excellent physical or chemical properties. However, the honeycomb size of ZnO prepared by these methods is on the order of microns, limiting the reactivity compared with those of a nanoscale honeycomb, and the honeycomb dimension cannot be controlled flexibly.
Hence, in this study, nano-carbon spheres with good monodispersity and a controllable particle size were prepared by a hydrothermal method. Then, three-dimensional (3D) honeycombstructured ZnO nanomaterials were prepared by coating ZnO on this template. The structural and morphological characterizations were carried out, and the photocatalytic properties and mechanism of the prepared materials were discussed. The results obtained herein serve as a reference for the controlled preparation of 3D honeycomb-structured ZnO nano-photocatalytic materials.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental
sections.text:
Nano-carbon spheres were prepared by a hydrothermal method. First, glucose was dissolved in deionized water to prepare a 0.05 mol/L solution. Then, the solution was transferred into a hydrothermal reactor at a specific temperature (160, 180 and 200 C) for a certain time (4, 6 and 8 h). Finally, the products were washed and dried at 60 C. Next, the prepared carbon-spheres (160 C and 4 h) were immersed in deionized water at a solid-toliquid mass ratio of 1:30. The pH of the system was adjusted to 5.6 using acetic acid. According to the carbon sphere to zinc acetate (C:Zn) molar ratios of 2:1, 1:1, 1:2, and 1:3, the zinc salt solution (0.5 mol/L) and the alkali solution (mass concentration
of 7%) were simultaneously dropped slowly into the stirred system. Zn(OH)2/carbon sphere composites were prepared after centrifugation, washed, and dried at 60 C. Thus the honeycomb-structured ZnO samples were obtained after heating Zn(OH)2/carbon sphere composites at 600 C for 1 h.
The morphology of the carbon spheres and ZnO nanomaterials were observed with a Carl Zeiss Ultra 55 field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM). The structural characterizations were performed via a PANalytical X’ Pert PRO X-ray diffractometer (XRD) with Cu Ka radiation. The photocatalytic performance of ZnO products was evaluated using methylene blue as model pollutant. Each ZnO sample (1 mg) was respectively placed in 250 mL solution of methylene blue (0.6 mg/L). A 100W mercury lamp (wavelength of 365–400 nm) was hung at 20 cm above the solution. The suspension was stirred for 1 h in dark. Take a sample every 30 min and measure the absorbance at the maximum absorption wavelength of the dye (k = 664 nm) by a Shimadzu UV-3150 UV– visible-near infrared spectroscopy. The degradation (g) was calculated according to the formula, g = [(A0 A)/A0] 100%, where A0 is the absorbance before the reaction and A is the absorbance after the reaction.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
Fig. 1 (a), (b), and (c) show the FE-SEM images of carbon spheres prepared at different hydrothermal reaction temperatures. Carbon spheres with good sphericity and dispersibility are prepared by a hydrothermal reaction at 160, 180, and 200 C for 240 min, with carbon sphere particle sizes of 80, 120, and 150 nm, respectively. With the increase in the reaction temperature, the particle size of carbon spheres increases. Fig. 1 (b), (d), and (e) show the FE-SEM images of the carbon spheres obtained at different reaction times at a temperature of 180 C. At a reaction time of 4 h, carbon spheres exhibit a clear interface and good monodispersity. However, with the reaction time increased to 6 h, the particle size slightly increases with a vague interface and clearly worse dispersion. With the further increase of reaction time to 8 h, agglomeration becomes more severe. Hence, the size of carbon spheres can be controlled by adjusting the hydrothermal reaction temperature, but an extremely long reaction time aggravates the dissolution and aggregation of the carbon spheres.
Fig. 2 shows the FE-SEM images of the 3D honeycombstructured ZnO nanomaterials fabricated at C: Zn molar ratios of 2:1, 1:1, 1:2, and 1:3. At the molar ratio of 2:1, owing to the decomposition of carbon spheres in Zn(OH)2/carbon sphere composites, ZnO with an irregular porous structure is formed, but the hole wall is relatively thick. At the molar ratio of 1:1, ZnO is formed with a 3D honeycomb-like structure, and the honeycomb size is 80 nm, exhibiting large porosity and a thin pore wall with thickness of 10–20 nm. However, at the molar ratio of 1:2, 3D honeycomb-like porous material is not formed, possibly related to the formation of an excess amount of ZnO caused by excess zinc acetate. At the molar ratio of 1:3, the excess of ZnO leads to further decrease in the porosity, and the voids are predominantly distributed on the aggregate surface of ZnO nanoparticles. Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of ZnO samples prepared with different C: Zn molar ratios. It shows that diffraction peaks corresponding to ZnO nanomaterials are in agreement with standard ZnO (PDF#036-1451), indicative of the hexagonal crystal system with a P63mc space group. No impurities or other phases exist.
Fig. 4 shows the catalytic degradation curves of the methylene blue solution by commercial ZnO (particle size of 5 lm) and 3D honeycomb-structured ZnO nanomaterials. All of the ZnO exhibited obvious photocatalytic degradation ability for methylene blue. Compared to commercial ZnO, the synthesized ZnO nanomaterials exhibit relatively superior photocatalytic degradation performance. However, the ZnO nanostructures prepared with different C: Zn molar ratios exhibit different photocatalytic abilities. At the molar ratio of 1:1, the product exhibits the best photocatalytic degradation behavior. The degradation rate of methylene blue reaches 95% within 90 min, exhibiting an enhancement of 108% compared with that observed for conventional micron-sized ZnO. The discussion above reveals that the particle size of the ZnO is on the order of nanometers, with a surface area considerably greater than that of the microparticles. In addition, the surface adsorption capacity and activity are better. At the molar ratio of 1:1, ZnO exhibits many open 3D honeycomb-like pore structures and thin pore walls, endowing the material high specific surface area and increased number of surface-active sites; hence, the photocatalytic degradation performance is effectively improved.
ZnO is a semiconductor with a band gap of 3.4 eV at room temperature [9]. Under ultraviolet-light irradiation, the electrons

in the valence band are driven to shift into the conduction band and generate electron–hole pairs. The electron–hole pairs separate and migrate to the particle surface under the application of an electric field, followed by the reaction with water and dissolved oxygen to produce highly chemically active hydroxyl groups ( OH) and peroxide groups (HO2 ). Then, these groups convert the oxygen absorbed on the catalyst surface into highly active oxygen, leading to a redox reaction with methylene blue to degrade it [10,11]. The results reveal that the 3D honeycomb-structured ZnO nanomaterials exhibit strong photocatalytic degradation ability for methylene blue and that the honeycomb size can be controlled by adjusting experimental parameters, and their surface adsorption capacity and photocatalytic activity can be enhanced.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
3D honeycomb-structed ZnO nanomaterials were prepared by a liquid-phase coating method using nano-carbon spheres as the template, which were prepared by a hydrothermal method. The honeycomb size and pore structure can be effectively controlled by the size of the nano-carbon spheres (adjusting the hydrothermal reaction temperature) and C: Zn molar ratio in the coating reaction. The honeycomb-like ZnO nanomaterials exhibit high specific surface area and more active sites, effectively improving their photocatalytic degradation performance. The degradation rate of methylene blue by the synthesized ZnO with a honeycomb size of 80 nm and pore wall thickness of 10 nm reached 95% in
90 min, with an increase of 108% compared with that by conventional micron-sized ZnO.
